overview: This Act shall be known and may be cited as the Judiciary Appropriations Act of 2025. [13] The purpose of this measure is to appropriate funds for the operating and capital improvement costs of the Judiciary for the fiscal biennium beginning on July 1, 2025, and ending on June 30, 2027. [14] The bill appropriates funds for the Judiciary for the fiscal biennium beginning 7/1/2025 and ending 6/30/2027. [13]
appropriations: This budget measure, as amended, appropriates operating totals from general funds of $201,725,676 for FY 2025-2026 and $199,579,345 for FY 2026-2027. [14] Of the general fund appropriation for administration (JUD601), the legislative document specifies the sum of $2,218,922 (HB400_CD1_.HTM.txt) or so much thereof as may be necessary for fiscal year 2025-2026 shall be expended for salary adjustments. [13] The legislative document appropriates capital improvement totals from general obligation bonds of $12,900,000 (HB400_CD1_.HTM.txt) for FY 2025-2026. [14]
assumptions_and_methodology: The sums appropriated or authorized are sufficient to accomplish the purposes and programs designated for the fiscal biennium beginning July 1, 2025, and ending June 30, 2027. [13] Your Committee on Conference has amended this measure by inserting appropriate operating and capital improvement amounts for fiscal biennium 2025-2027. [14] The total expenditures established in each fiscal year shall not exceed the sums indicated for each year, except as provided in this Act. [13]
agency_impact: The chief justice, in administering an equitable and expeditious judicial process, may transfer sufficient funds and positions between programs for operating purposes. [13] The judiciary may delegate to other state or county agencies the planning, acquisition of land, design, construction, and equipment of any capital improvement project when it is determined by the judiciary to be advantageous to do so. [13] The chief justice may also authorize a reduction of project scope where it has been determined that changed conditions permit it. [13]
economic_impact: The provided legislative documents are for appropriations and do not describe specific economic impacts. [13] The bill provides for capital improvement projects for economic development, including plans, design, construction, and equipment for general alterations, upgrades, and improvements to judiciary facilities, statewide. [13] Funding is also provided for plans and design for a new South Kohala District Courthouse on Hawaii Island. [13]
policy_impact: This Act shall be known and may be cited as the Judiciary Appropriations Act of 2025. [13] The measure allows the chief justice to transfer funds between programs, supplement funds for capital improvement projects from other cost elements of the same project, and make supplemental allotments from the judiciary project adjustment fund. [13] [13] [13] Appropriations for capital improvement projects shall not lapse at the end of the fiscal year, but all appropriations made for fiscal year 2025-2026 and fiscal year 2026-2027 that are unencumbered as of June 30, 2028, shall lapse as of that date. [13]
revenue_sources: The sources of funding are specified as general funds (A), special funds (B), general obligation bond funds (C), and revolving funds (W). [13] The legislative document specifies that general obligation bonds may be issued to finance projects, provided that the sum total of the general obligation bonds so issued shall not exceed $12,900,000 (HB400_CD1_.HTM.txt). [13] The bill provides that the chief justice may secure federal funds or funds from private organizations or individuals to be expended in connection with any program. [13]
six_year_fiscal_implications: The measure appropriates funds for the operating and capital improvement costs of the Judiciary for the fiscal biennium beginning on July 1, 2025, and ending on June 30, 2027. [14] As amended, this budget measure appropriates operating totals from general funds of $201,725,676 for FY 2025-2026 and $199,579,345 for FY 2026-2027. [14] All means of finance for operating totals are $214,571,429 for FY 2025-2026 and $212,425,098 for FY 2026-2027. [14] Of the general fund appropriation for administration, the legislative document specifies a sum of $2,218,922 (HB400_CD1_.HTM.txt) is provided for fiscal year 2025-2026 for salary adjustments. [13] The legislative document specifies capital improvement projects are funded by $12,900,000 (HB400_CD1_.HTM.txt) in general obligation bonds for FY 2025-2026. [14] The total expenditures and the number of permanent and temporary positions established in each fiscal year of the fiscal biennium shall not exceed the sums and the position ceilings indicated. [13] For the First Judicial Circuit, the position ceiling is 1,115.50 permanent and 57.58 temporary positions for each year. [13] For Administration, the position ceiling is 234.50 permanent and 8.48 temporary positions for each year. [13] The appropriations made for capital improvement projects shall not lapse at the end of the fiscal year for which the appropriations are made. [13] All unencumbered capital appropriations as of June 30, 2028, shall lapse as of that date. [13]
operating_revenue_impact: The judiciary may transfer savings from its general fund appropriation to the driver education and training fund to accommodate any temporary cash flow deficits. [13] The chief justice may secure federal funds or other property under any act of Congress, or any funds or other property from private organizations or individuals. [13] The provided documents do not identify any other specific impacts to operating revenues. [13]
capital_expenditure_impact: The legislative document specifies the sum of $12,900,000 (HB400_CD1_.HTM.txt) is appropriated for capital improvement projects to be expended by the judiciary. [13] Projects listed include $900,000 for the Kauai Judiciary Complex Chiller Replacement, $8,000,000 for Lump Sum CIP for Judiciary Facilities, Statewide, and $4,000,000 for the South Kohala District Courthouse. [13] [13] [13] General obligation bonds may be issued, as provided by law, to yield the amount that may be necessary to finance these projects. [13]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: Appropriations for capital improvement projects authorized in this Act that are unencumbered as of June 30, 2028, shall lapse as of that date. [13] All unrequired balances in the general obligation bond fund after the objectives of the appropriations have been met shall be transferred to the judiciary project adjustment fund. [13] The provided documents do not detail ongoing fiscal obligations beyond the 2025-2027 biennium and the 2028 lapse date. [13]
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: This fiscal note is based on the final conference draft of the bill. [14] The amended measure appropriates general fund operating totals of $201,725,676 for Fiscal Year 2025-2026 and $199,579,345 for Fiscal Year 2026-2027, which are different from the amounts in the previous version of the bill. [14] This version of the bill does not contain the specific appropriations for civil legal services and immigration-related legal services that were in the prior version; instead, it provides that of the general fund appropriation for administration (JUD601), the legislative document specifies the sum of $2,218,922 (HB400_CD1_.HTM.txt) shall be expended for salary adjustments in FY 2025-2026. [13] The capital improvement appropriation from general obligation bonds remains $12,900,000 (HB400_CD1_.HTM.txt) for FY 2025-2026. [14] The effective date of the measure has been changed to July 1, 2025, from the previous placeholder date. [13] [14]
